page.title: 08TOURISM IN IGHTHAM
page.content: {Town House}- one of the best known Tudor houses in the District is said to be the oldest dwelling in the village - the name came into use in the {18th century}and meant {"the {house belonging to Town Farm".}Before this time it was known as{'Thrupps {Tenement'.} The building is a{listed Grade {11}property of the{15th & 16th {centuries,}a framed structure forming its core. There is a large central Hall with an open timber roof, the principle features of which are the massive oak beams, King Post roof trusses, Inglenook fireplaces and open stone fireplaces. The elevations to the street have gables to left and right with a first floor overhang. The two moulded {bressummers}to the right are carved with cornice battlements (possibly 15th century) and the left
